title: Asymmetric Mobility Intro
text: initial values geographic locations. list containing 1 mobility matrix per time period (4 time periods per day, 5 days = 20 time periods). mobility matrix must contain non-diagonal links (.e. every geographical location combination must included, except people “staying home”) One beta per time period.
code: spread::asymmetric_mobility_dummy_seiiar_pop #>    location_code    S E  I Ia R #> 1:             a 1000 0 50  0 0 #> 2:             b 1000 0  0  0 0 #> 3:             c 2000 0  0  0 0 length(spread::asymmetric_mobility_dummy_mobility_matrix) #> [1] 20 spread::asymmetric_mobility_dummy_mobility_matrix[[1]] #>    from to  n #> 1:    a  b 50 #> 2:    a  c 10 #> 3:    b  a 10 #> 4:    b  c 10 #> 5:    c  a 10 #> 6:    c  b 10 spread::asymmetric_mobility_dummy_betas #>  [1] 0.6 0.6 0.6 0.6 0.6 0.6 0.6 0.6 0.6 0.6 0.6 0.6 0.6 0.6 0.6 0.6 0.6 0.6 0.6 #> [20] 0.6

title: Asymmetric Mobility Intro
text: b_* variables represent status people belonging particular geographical location. c_* variables represent current status people existing geographical location time point.

title: Simple Branching Process Model
text: show use branching process model modelling potential spread SARS-like corona virus. branching process model takes information basic reproduction number, serial interval dispersion parameter can make short term forecasts number new cases. current model take account depletion suceptibles introduction control measures. Following Lipsitch et Al 2003 use value R0 3 serial interval mean 8.4 days SD 3.4 days. also set dispersion parameter 0.16 following Lloyd-Smith et Al 2005.    median number cases around 50, probability spread around 6%.
code: library(ggplot2) library(epitrix)  #Defining the serial interval  mu <- 8.4 sd <- 3.4 param <- epitrix::gamma_mucv2shapescale(mu, sd/mu) si <-   distcrete::distcrete("gamma", interval = 1,                 shape = param$shape,                 scale = param$scale, w = 0)   incidences <- spread::branching_process(initial_cases=1,                                          R0=1.4,                          dispersion=1,                          serial_interval=si,                          days_simulation=30,                          simulations=1000) summary <- spread::summarize_bp(incidences) spread::plot_quantiles_bp(incidences) + ggtitle("Estimated daily incidence") + xlab("Days") + ylab("Incidence") spread::plot_quantiles_bp(summary$cumulative) + ggtitle("Estimated cumulative case counts")  + xlab("Days") + ylab("cumulative Cases") ggplot() + geom_histogram(aes(x=colSums(incidences))) +theme_minimal() +ggtitle("Distribution of number of cases after 30 days") + xlab("N cases after 30 days") print(median(summary$cumulative[30,])) #> [1] 5 print(summary$p_no_spread) #> [1] 0.274

what: Estimating parameters via approximate Bayesian computation (ABC)
title: Simple Branching Process Model
text: can also estimate R0 know number cases time t. assume 2000 4000 cases 56 days. One can also vary parameters include uncertainty
code: mu <- 8.4 sd <- 3.4 param <- epitrix::gamma_mucv2shapescale(mu, sd/mu) si <-   distcrete::distcrete("gamma", interval = 1,                 shape = param$shape,                 scale = param$scale, w = 0) params <- list() for(R0 in seq(from=1, to=10, by=0.05)){     params[[length(params)+1]] <- list(       initial_cases=1,                       R0=R0,       dispersion=1,       serial_interval=si,       days_simulation=56     ) }  r <- spread::fit_params_bp(   cases_min = 2000,   cases_max = 3000,    param_list = params,    simulations=1000   ) #> Warning: UNRELIABLE VALUE: One of the 'future.apply' iterations #> ('future_lapply-1') unexpectedly generated random numbers without declaring so. #> There is a risk that those random numbers are not statistically sound and the #> overall results might be invalid. To fix this, specify 'future.seed=TRUE'. This #> ensures that proper, parallel-safe random numbers are produced via the L'Ecuyer- #> CMRG method. To disable this check, use 'future.seed = NULL', or set option #> 'future.rng.onMisuse' to "ignore". print(HDInterval::hdi(r$R0)) #> lower upper  #>   2.1   4.5  #> attr(,"credMass") #> [1] 0.95

title: Commuter Model Intro
text: model stochastic SEIIaR (susceptible, exposed, infectious, infectious asymptomatic, recovered) metapopulation model. location local infection system, locations connected people commute day. model differentiates day night. day can infect/infected location work, night can infect/infected location live. commuters travel back forth day. start day, commuters sent work location, mix 12 hours. commuters sent respective home locations, mix 12 hours. model loosely based upon published model Engebretsen (2019).

title: Commuter Model Intro
text: seiiar dataset contains following variables entire population want model: location_code code location S starting value susceptible people E starting value exposed people starting value infectious symptomatic people Ia starting value infectious asymptomatic people R starting value recovered people commuters dataset contains following variables: location code location people live location code location people work n number people applies r0 basic reproductive number. latent_period average number days person exposed infectious. asymptomatic_prob probability infectious person asymptomatic. asymptomatic_relative_infectiousness relative infectiousness asymptomatic infectious person compared symptomatic infectious person. value 0 1. days_simulation number days want simulate. N number simulations run results averaged. generally set 1, unless performing model fitting.
code: library(ggplot2) library(data.table) # no one in Norway is infected, and everyone is susceptible spread::norway_seiiar_noinfected_2017_b2020 #>      location_code      S E I Ia R #>   1:   municip0301 666759 0 0  0 0 #>   2:   municip1101  14899 0 0  0 0 #>   3:   municip1103 140856 0 0  0 0 #>   4:   municip1106  37166 0 0  0 0 #>   5:   municip1108  76742 0 0  0 0 #>  ---                               #> 352:   municip5440    991 0 0  0 0 #> 353:   municip5441   2911 0 0  0 0 #> 354:   municip5442    951 0 0  0 0 #> 355:   municip5443   2267 0 0  0 0 #> 356:   municip5444  10199 0 0  0 0  # 10 people in Oslo are infected, and everyone is susceptible spread::norway_seiiar_oslo_2017_b2020 #>      location_code      S E  I Ia R #>   1:   municip0301 666749 0 10  0 0 #>   2:   municip1101  14899 0  0  0 0 #>   3:   municip1103 140856 0  0  0 0 #>   4:   municip1106  37166 0  0  0 0 #>   5:   municip1108  76742 0  0  0 0 #>  ---                                #> 352:   municip5440    991 0  0  0 0 #> 353:   municip5441   2911 0  0  0 0 #> 354:   municip5442    951 0  0  0 0 #> 355:   municip5443   2267 0  0  0 0 #> 356:   municip5444  10199 0  0  0 0  # no one in Norway is infected, and childhood vaccination data is used to # estimate the number of "recovered" (i.e. non-susceptible) people for measles spread::norway_seiiar_measles_noinfected_2017_b2020 #>      location_code     S E I Ia      R #>   1:   municip0301 59775 0 0  0 606984 #>   2:   municip1101  1027 0 0  0  13872 #>   3:   municip1103  8868 0 0  0 131988 #>   4:   municip1106  1557 0 0  0  35609 #>   5:   municip1108  3058 0 0  0  73684 #>  ---                                   #> 352:   municip5440    56 0 0  0    935 #> 353:   municip5441   513 0 0  0   2398 #> 354:   municip5442    72 0 0  0    879 #> 355:   municip5443   150 0 0  0   2117 #> 356:   municip5444  1149 0 0  0   9050  # 10 people in Oslo is infected, and childhood vaccination data is used to # estimate the number of "recovered" (i.e. non-susceptible) people for measles spread::norway_seiiar_measles_oslo_2017_b2020 #>      location_code     S E  I Ia      R #>   1:   municip0301 59765 0 10  0 606984 #>   2:   municip1101  1027 0  0  0  13872 #>   3:   municip1103  8868 0  0  0 131988 #>   4:   municip1106  1557 0  0  0  35609 #>   5:   municip1108  3058 0  0  0  73684 #>  ---                                    #> 352:   municip5440    56 0  0  0    935 #> 353:   municip5441   513 0  0  0   2398 #> 354:   municip5442    72 0  0  0    879 #> 355:   municip5443   150 0  0  0   2117 #> 356:   municip5444  1149 0  0  0   9050  # we can take a closer look at Oslo spread::norway_seiiar_measles_oslo_2017_b2020[location_code=="municip0301"] #>    location_code     S E  I Ia      R #> 1:   municip0301 59765 0 10  0 606984 # we provide the number of municipal commuters in Norway in 2017 spread::norway_commuters_2017_b2020 #>               from          to    n #>     1: municip0301 municip1101   71 #>     2: municip0301 municip1103 1423 #>     3: municip0301 municip1106  332 #>     4: municip0301 municip1108  652 #>     5: municip0301 municip1111    5 #>    ---                              #> 23948: municip5444 municip5439    3 #> 23949: municip5444 municip5440    1 #> 23950: municip5444 municip5441   33 #> 23951: municip5444 municip5442   12 #> 23952: municip5444 municip5443    8

title: Commuter Model Intro
text: simulate one measles outbreak using datasets spread::norway_seiiar_measles_oslo_2017_b2020 spread::norway_commuters_2017_b2020: Inspecting data Oslo: can merge information counties, create county level data: can produce daily epicurve county:  can produce weekly maps:
code: set.seed(4) d <- spread::commuter(   seiiar=spread::norway_seiiar_measles_oslo_2017_b2020,   commuters=spread::norway_commuters_2017_b2020,   r0=14,   latent_period = 8,   infectious_period = 5,   asymptomatic_prob=0,   asymptomatic_relative_infectiousness=0,   days_simulation=7*9,   N=1 ) #> Starting to add edges, printing every 1000 edge #> 1000 2000 3000 4000 5000 6000 7000 8000 9000 10000 11000 12000 13000 14000 15000 16000 17000 18000 19000 20000 21000 22000 23000 Found 23894 edges #> Running 1 simulations of 63 days #>  #>  #> Finished all simulations d[location_code=="municip0301"] municip0301    9  63   TRUE 59701 13 7  0 607039         3 666760 #>     sim_id location_code week day is_6pm     S  E I Ia      R incidence    pop d[   fhidata::norway_locations_hierarchy(from = "municip", to = "county"),   on = "location_code==from_code",   county_code := to_code ] d[   fhidata::norway_locations_names(),   on = "county_code==location_code",   county_name := location_name      ]  county <- d[,.(   S=sum(S),   E=sum(E),   I=sum(I),   Ia=sum(Ia),   R=sum(R),   incidence=sum(incidence),   pop=sum(pop) ), keyby=.(county_code,county_name,week,day,is_6pm)] county[,county_name:=factor(county_name,levels=unique(fhidata::norway_locations_b2020[,c("county_code","county_name")]$county_name))] county #>      county_code       county_name week day is_6pm     S E I Ia      R #>   1:    county03              Oslo    1   1   TRUE 59764 2 9  0 606985 #>   2:    county03              Oslo    1   2   TRUE 59761 4 7  0 606988 #>   3:    county03              Oslo    1   3   TRUE 59760 4 5  0 606991 #>   4:    county03              Oslo    1   4   TRUE 59759 5 4  0 606992 #>   5:    county03              Oslo    1   5   TRUE 59759 5 2  0 606994 #>  ---                                                                   #> 689:    county54 Troms og Finnmark    9  59   TRUE 22632 0 0  0 220397 #> 690:    county54 Troms og Finnmark    9  60   TRUE 22632 0 0  0 220397 #> 691:    county54 Troms og Finnmark    9  61   TRUE 22632 0 0  0 220397 #> 692:    county54 Troms og Finnmark    9  62   TRUE 22632 0 0  0 220397 #> 693:    county54 Troms og Finnmark    9  63   TRUE 22632 0 0  0 220397 #>      incidence    pop #>   1:         0 666760 #>   2:         1 666760 #>   3:         1 666760 #>   4:         0 666760 #>   5:         0 666760 #>  ---                  #> 689:         0 243029 #> 690:         0 243029 #> 691:         0 243029 #> 692:         0 243029 #> 693:         0 243029 p <- ggplot(county, aes(x=day, y=incidence)) p <- p + geom_col() p <- p + facet_wrap(~county_name) p <- p + scale_x_continuous("Day") p w <- county[,.(   incidence_weekly = sum(incidence),   pop = mean(pop) ), keyby=.(county_code, week)]  w[,weekly_incidence_per_10000 := 10000*incidence_weekly/pop] w[,facet:=glue::glue("Week {week}",week=week)]  pd <- merge(   w,   fhimaps::norway_nuts3_map_b2020_default_dt,    by.x="county_code",   by.y="location_code",   allow.cartesian = T)  p <- ggplot(data=pd, mapping=aes( x = long, y = lat, group = group)) p <- p + geom_polygon(aes(fill=weekly_incidence_per_10000)) p <- p + facet_wrap(~facet) p <- p + theme_void() p <- p + coord_quickmap() p

title: Authors and Citation
text: package proudly brought : Solveig Engebretsen. Author. Andreas Nygård Osnes. Author. Gunnar Rø. Author. Richard Aubrey White. Author, maintainer. . Copyright holder. See changelog contributors. 🙏

title: Authors and Citation
text: Engebretsen S, Osnes , Rø G, White RA (2022). spread: Infectious Disease Spread Models. https://docs.sykdomspulsen./spread, https://github.com/sykdomspulsen-org/spread.
code: @Manual{,   title = {spread: Infectious Disease Spread Models},   author = {Solveig Engebretsen and Andreas Nygård Osnes and Gunnar Rø and Richard Aubrey White},   year = {2022},   note = {https://docs.sykdomspulsen.no/spread, https://github.com/sykdomspulsen-org/spread}, }

title: Infectious Disease Spread Models
text: spread contains different infectious disease spread models. Currently implemented commuter model. model stochastic SEIIaR (susceptible, exposed, infectious, infectious asymptomatic, recovered) metapopulation model including commuting. location local infection system, locations connected people commute day. model differentiates day night. day can infect/infected location work, night can infect/infected location live. commuters travel back forth day. start day, commuters sent work location, mix 12 hours. commuters sent respective home locations, mix 12 hours. model based upon published model. Read introduction vignette run help(package="spread").

title: Infectious Disease Spread Models
text: splverse set R packages developed help solve problems frequently occur performing infectious disease surveillance. want install dev versions (access packages haven’t released CRAN), run usethis::edit_r_profile() edit .Rprofile. write : Save file restart R. can now install splverse packages drat repository.
code: options(   repos = structure(c(     SPLVERSE  = "https://docs.sykdomspulsen.no/drat/",     CRAN      = "https://cran.rstudio.com"   )) ) install.packages("spread")

title: asymmetric mobility — asymmetric_mobility
text: seiiar_pop Data frame containing `location_code`, `S`, `E`, ``, `Ia`, `R` entire population mobility_matrix List (1 entry time period) entry containing data frame ``, ``, `n` number people travel. data frame must complete. dynamic_seeds Data.table containing `location_code`, `day`, `n` dynamic seeding (`NULL`) betas Vector (1 entry time period). Float, infection parameter, 0.6 latent_period Float, 1.9 infectious_period Float, 3 asymptomatic_prob Float, Proportion/probability asymptomatic given infectious asymptomatic_relative_infectiousness Float, Relative infectiousness asymptomatic infectious N Int = 1 int, Number internal simulations (average taken). generally used parameter fitting.

title: commuter — commuter
text: seiiar Data frame containing `location_code`, `S`, `E`, ``, `Ia`, `R` entire population commuters Data frame comtaining ``, ``, `n` number people travel r0 Float, basic reproduction number beta Float, infection parameter, 0.6 latent_period Float, 1.9 infectious_period Float, 3 asymptomatic_prob Float, Proportion/probability asymptomatic given infectious asymptomatic_relative_infectiousness Float, Relative infectiousness asymptomatic infectious days_simulation Int, Number days simulate N Int = 1 int, Number internal simulations (average taken). generally used parameter fitting. simulations Int, Number simulations (returned). generally used generate stochastic results. verbose boolean seed seed aggregate_location want aggregate location_codes?

title: commuter — commuter
text: year middle year 5 year range (e.g. 2011 average data 2009-2013). location_code location code. age population age. vax vaccine. proportion Proportion people vaccinated. imputed FALSE real data. TRUE national average.

title: commuter — commuter
text: location local infection system, locations connected people commute day. model differentiates day night. day can infect/infected location work, night can infect/infected location live. commuters travel back forth day. start day, commuters sent work location, mix 12 hours. commuters sent respective home locations, mix 12 hours. model loosely based upon published model Engebretsen (2019) doi: 10.1371/journal.pcbi.1006879 . information, look vignette("commuter_model","spread")

title: spread 2020.1.30
text: Included option “aggregate_location” commuter function. automatically aggregate results locations, resulting smaller memory footprint. Useful simulations large number.

title: spread 2020.1.28
text: Included option “simulations” (number simulations repeated) commuter function via foreach loop, allowing simulations run parallel desired (backend must registered externally package).

text: Included option “verbose” commuter function.
